comments.content:
I agree, Correct answer is False:
https://help.salesforce.com/articleView?id=customize_rename_considerations.htm&type=5
After renaming tabs, objects, or fields, check the following additional items that may need manual updates:
-Review all list view names. List view names continue to display the original object name until you change them manually.
-Check standard report names and descriptions for the objects you renamed.
-Update the titles and descriptions of any email templates that contain the original object or field name.
-Manually change any other items you customized with the new object or field name. For example, custom fields, page layouts, and record types may contain the original tab or field name.

questions.question_text: If a Standard Object is Renamed, the Reports are Renamed based on the new label value

comments.content:
The question didn't ask about mapping during a lead conversion, it asked if a custom lead field could be mapped to a case. (and it can) Custom fields can't be mapped to Case on Lead conversion, but that doesn't invalidate the answer in this case. 
Correct answer is true.

For each custom lead field, choose a custom account, contact, or opportunity field into which you want the information inserted when you convert a lead. In Lightning Experience, a custom lead field can map to account, contact, and opportunity fields at the same time.

questions.question_text: You can map a custom lead field to a Case
Picklist dependency rules are not enforced during Import

discussion.content:
The Data Import Wizard doesn’t consider field dependencies. You can import any value into a dependent picklist regardless of the value imported for a controlling field.
CORRECT ANSWER IS TRUE
Correct answer is false. If picklist dependency exists, you cannot import a record where the child dependency do not match

questions.question_text: What is the limit on the compiled size of the Formula Field Select the correct choice?

discussion.content:
Compile size limit —Formula fields can’t exceed 15,000 bytes when compiled. The compile size is the size of the formula (in bytes) including all of the fields, values, and formulas it references. There’s no direct correlation between the compile size and the character limit. Some functions, such as TEXT, DATEVALUE, DATETIMEVALUE, and DATE significantly increase the compile size.
(https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.formula_field_limits.htm&type=5)
https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.formula_field_limits.htm&type=5 4000 bytes when saved and 15 000 bytes when compiled

Answer is 5k:
Compile size limit—Formula fields can’t exceed 5,000 bytes when compiled. The compile size is the size of the formula (in bytes) including all of the fields, values, and formulas it references. There is no direct correlation between the compile size and the character limit. Some functions, such as TEXT, DATEVALUE, DATETIMEVALUE, and DATE significantly increase the compile size.
